required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Wheezing in Black Preterm Infants: Impact of Vitamin D Supplementation Strategy
clinical_study.official_title: Wheezing in Black Preterm Infants: Impact of Vitamin D Supplementation Strategy

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to identify a vitamin D supplementation strategy that best promotes the lung, immune, and overall health of black infants born preterm (28-36 weeks gestational age). This is a high risk population that seems to have unique vitamin D needs, and inappropriate supplementation may promote wheezing or allergy. The results of this study will help form nutritional recommendations for the approximately 100,000 black infants born at 30-36 weeks gestational age in the U.S. every year.

detailed_description.textblock: Black infants face the highest rates of prematurity in the U.S. (18%), have high rates of prematurity-associated wheezing illnesses, and tend to have lower vitamin D levels. The goal of this [comparative effectiveness] study is to identify a vit. D supplementation strategy that minimizes recurrent wheezing in infancy. Long recognized as important for bone health, a growing body of evidence suggests that vit. D may play a role in the regulation and development of many organ systems. The D pathway regulates lung inflammation and impacts morphogenesis, structure, and cell growth and survival in bronchial smooth muscle. Vit. D exposure has the potential to skew cytokine expression from a Th1 (less allergic) to a Th2 (more allergic) phenotype. Due to their developmental immaturity, preterm infants may be particularly vulnerable to any positive or negative effects of vit. D supplementation on the lung, airway, and immune system. Our preliminary data, supported by the literature, suggests that overly aggressive vit. D supplementation may inadvertently increase wheezing in infancy in black, but not white, preterm infants; however, vit. D deficiency could theoretically also increase wheezing via vulnerability to respiratory pathogens. The proposed study is a randomized clinical trial comparing the effect of two different enteral vitamin D supplementation strategies on recurrent wheezing in infancy in 300 black infants born preterm at 28 0/7-36 6/7 wks gestational age, a population for whom neither vit. D requirements nor optimal vit. D serum levels have been established. The investigators will test two strategies: (I) sustained supplementation until 6 mo. of age adjusted for prematurity, and (II) cessation of supplementation when a minimum dietary intake of 200 IU/day is reached. The specific aims are to characterize the effect of each strategy on (aim 1) recurrent wheezing and (aim 2) allergic sensitization and atopy. The investigators will (aim 3) explore the relationship between vit. D serum levels and recurrent wheezing. The investigators hypothesize that strategy II will be more effective in promoting pulmonary health by minimizing recurrent wheezing, allergic sensitization, and overall healthcare utilization, and will be sufficient to prevent clinical vit. D deficiency. The investigators also hypothesize that optimal vit. D serum levels will be lower than the norms for other populations.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Infants With Recurrent Wheezing
primary_outcome.description: Recurrent wheezing was defined as more than 1 episode of wheezing reported during the study period. Separate episodes were defined as occurring at least 2 weeks apart.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number With Infants With Allergic Sensitization as Measured by the PhadiaTop Infant Assay
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at the 12 month adjusted age visit
secondary_outcome.description: Measured using the Phadiatop Infant IgE panel

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at the 12 month adjusted age visit
secondary_outcome.description: Measured by bone speed of sound (ultrasound)

arm_group.description: Infants will remain on 400 IU/day of cholecalciferol until 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity, regardless of dietary intake
Infants will receive placebo once their dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/day

intervention.description: Once the dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/Day, the infants will receive placebo until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity
Infants will receive cholecalciferol 400 IU/day PO until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Infants were recruited from participating NICUs, special care nurseries, and well-baby nurseries.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: If all eligibility labs were not available from routine clinical care, parents were consented prior to obtaining the remaining eligibility labs. If those post-consent laboratory results made the infant ineligible, they were not randomized.

group.title: Sustained
group.description: Infants will remain on 400 IU/day of cholecalciferol until 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity, regardless of dietary intake Cholecalciferol: Infants will receive cholecalciferol 400 IU/day PO until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

group.title: Diet-Limited
group.description: Infants will receive placebo once their dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/day Cholecalciferol: Once the dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/Day from formula or fortifiers, the infants will receive placebo until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

baseline.population: One infant was withdrawn from the study prior to completion of the baseline questionnaire a data collection, and is not included all rows in this table.

Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

group.title: Diet-Limited
group.description: Infants will receive placebo once their dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/day Cholecalciferol: Once the dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/Day from formula or fortifiers, the infants will receive placebo until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

outcome.title: Number of Infants With Recurrent Wheezing
outcome.description: Recurrent wheezing was defined as more than 1 episode of wheezing reported during the study period. Separate episodes were defined as occurring at least 2 weeks apart.
outcome.population: Infants that were withdrawn, completely lost to follow-up, who died, or for whom recurrent wheezing status was indeterminate due to a missing 12 month visit (n=8) were not included in the primary analysis.

group.title: Sustained
group.description: Infants will remain on 400 IU/day of cholecalciferol until 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity, regardless of dietary intake Cholecalciferol: Infants will receive cholecalciferol 400 IU/day PO until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

group.title: Diet-Limited
group.description: Infants will receive placebo once their dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/day Cholecalciferol: Once the dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/Day from formula or fortifiers, the infants will receive placebo until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

measure.title: Number of Infants With Recurrent Wheezing
measure.description: Recurrent wheezing was defined as more than 1 episode of wheezing reported during the study period. Separate episodes were defined as occurring at least 2 weeks apart.
measure.population: Infants that were withdrawn, completely lost to follow-up, who died, or for whom recurrent wheezing status was indeterminate due to a missing 12 month visit (n=8) were not included in the primary analysis.

analysis.method_desc: Poisson regression using GEE with robust variance estimation (e.g. Zou, American Journal Epidemiology, 2004)

outcome.description: Measured using the Phadiatop Infant IgE panel

analysis.groups_desc: For secondary outcomes, GEE is used to assess randomization arm association.

outcome.title: Bone Density
outcome.description: Measured by bone speed of sound (ultrasound)
outcome.time_frame: Measured at the 12 month adjusted age visit
outcome.population: Bone density was not performed if (1) infant could not come to the clinic for their 12 month visit and the visit was done in the home (2) they missed their 12 month visit (3) the ultrasound was under repair, or (4) infant could not participate with the ultrasound to get a sufficient quality reading.

group.title: Sustained
group.description: Infants will remain on 400 IU/day of cholecalciferol until 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity, regardless of dietary intake Cholecalciferol: Infants will receive cholecalciferol 400 IU/day PO until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

group.title: Diet-Limited
group.description: Infants will receive placebo once their dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/day Cholecalciferol: Once the dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/Day from formula or fortifiers, the infants will receive placebo until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

measure.title: Bone Density
measure.description: Measured by bone speed of sound (ultrasound)
measure.population: Bone density was not performed if (1) infant could not come to the clinic for their 12 month visit and the visit was done in the home (2) they missed their 12 month visit (3) the ultrasound was under repair, or (4) infant could not participate with the ultrasound to get a sufficient quality reading.

reported_events.desc: Study personnel screened for adverse events at each study visit. Adverse event categories/organ systems are not mutually exclusive (for instance, an AE could be coded under both respiratory and infectious categories). All significant associated symptoms/findings were coded for each (S)AE. 36 patients in the Sustained arm had a total of 44 SAEs; 38 patients in the Diet-Limited arm had a total of 56 SAEs. Some patients experienced more than one SAE.

group.title: Sustained
group.description: Infants will remain on 400 IU/day of cholecalciferol until 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity, regardless of dietary intake Cholecalciferol: Infants will receive cholecalciferol 400 IU/day PO until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

group.title: Diet-Limited
group.description: Infants will receive placebo once their dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/day Cholecalciferol: Once the dietary intake of vitamin D has exceeded 200 IU/Day from formula or fortifiers, the infants will receive placebo until they are 6 months of age adjusted for prematurity. Exclusively breastfed infants receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily as needed beyond 6 months adjusted age for the duration of the study.

event.description: This category was coded if the condition did not fit into the other pre-specified GI categories
This category was coded if the important signs or symptoms related to the event were was not otherwise described by other pre-existing categories.
This category was coded if the infection was not described by other pre-specified infection categories.
This category was coded if the condition was not described by another pre-existing neurologic category.
This category was coded if the event did not fit in the other pre-specified pulmonary categories for infections, wheezing, or apnea.
"Apparent Life Threatening Event" or "Brief Resolved Unexplained Event." The American Academy of Pediatrics preferred terminology changed during the study.
This category was coded if the event was not described by the other GI categories.
This category was coded if the relevant signs/symptoms of the AE were not otherwise captured by other categories.
This category was coded if the event was not described by another infection category.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
